Synthesis of cyclic carbonates of different epoxides using CO2 as a C1 building block over Ag/TUD-1 mesoporous silica catalyst: A solvent free approach Kumer Saurav Keshri Methodology Investigation Data curation Formal analysis Software Writing – original draft a Sudip Bhattacharjee Data curation Writing – original draft b Aniruddha Singha Formal analysis a Asim Bhaumik Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition b ⁎ Biswajit Chowdhury Conceptualization Project administration Supervision Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology (Indian School of Mines), Dhanbad, Jharkhand, 826004, India Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology (Indian School of Mines) Dhanbad Jharkhand 826004 India aDepartment of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology (Indian School of Mines), Dhanbad, Jharkhand, 826004, India b School of Materials Sciences, Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science, Kolkata, 700032, India School of Materials Sciences, Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science Kolkata 700032 India bSchool of Materials Sciences, Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science, Kolkata, 700032, India ⁎ Corresponding authors. Utilization of abandoned CO2 that is generated from fossil fuels and industrial sources into valuable chemicals is a smart approach for a greener future. The fixation of CO2 over epoxides and the production of cyclic carbonates is one of the popular CO2 utilization techniques. Silica supported silver nanoparticles have been used before in different important reactions like nitrophenol reduction, alcohol oxidation etc., due to the high surface area, pore size of silica and high activity of the Ag0 species. In this study, Technische Universiteit Delft -1 (TUD-1) is used as silica support for stabilizing silver nanoparticles and CO2 has been converted to cyclic carbonate under solvent less condition. The Lewis acidic nature of the silver particles have aided into the solvent-less CO2 conversion, resulting into the maximum yield of 98% at 60 °C and 1 MPa pressure. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 fixation Silver particles TUD-1 Solvent less Cyclic carbonates 1 Introduction Our dependence of fossil fuels as the primary source of energy caused a gruesome environmental hazard in the form of uninterrupted CO2 emission, which is summoning global warming, acidification of sea water, rise in the oceanic water level and related calamities [1,2]. Therefore, utilization of the excess CO2 into valuable chemicals has been one of the major research focusses for the scientists around the world [3–7]. Different scientific strategies are being taken to convert CO2 to useful chemicals, e.g. organic carbonates [8], organic carbamates [9], formaldehyde/methanol/formate [10,11] etc. Indeed, CO2 has been found as a cheaper and safer alternative compared to many industrial substrates [12]. One of such promising methods has been, the incorporation of CO2 into epoxide systems to produce respective cyclic carbonates [8,13]. The efficient catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates involve MOF [11], SiO2 [14,15] based catalysts. Silica based catalysts are important as they provide acidic functionality through their silanol (Si-OH) groups, which aid the activation of epoxides like propylene epoxide [16]. For that reason, silica has been used as effective support to immobilize halide salts [14,17] and ionic liquids [15] and utilize their catalytic abilities to convert CO2 to cyclic carbonates. Mesoporous mixed metal oxides also showed high catalytic activity in this CO2 cycloaddition reaction [18]. Moreover, metallic nanoparticles supported over mesoporous materials have gathered special attention due to their uniform pores and channels, high surface area, high adsorption strength and tunability of the active sites [2]. Silver based systems are also useful for CO2 fixation. Silver complexes [19] and silver based MOF [20] catalysts displayed optimum catalytic activity of the cyclic carbonate formation from CO2 and epoxides. Recently, silver active sites surrounded by gold nanoclusters have been found to be efficient in the ring-opening of epoxides and the incorporation of CO2 inside [21]. SiO2 supported silver nanoparticles have been already used in multiple reactions, like nitrophenol reduction [22], CO oxidation [23], diesel particulate matter oxidation [24], ethanol to hydrocarbons [25] etc. The high activity of Ag/SiO2 systems has been attributed to the subsurface oxygen species [26], the presence of metallic Ag0species [24] or smaller particle size [27]. Among different SiO2 supports, Technische Universiteit Delft −1 (TUD-1) is unique due to its sponge like nature, irregular pore structure and easy preparation procedure [28]. TUD-1 supported metal nanoparticle catalysts has been effective in versatile reactions, like toluene oxidation [29], styrene epoxidation [30], Baeyer-Villiger oxidation [31] etc. TUD-1 has acted like an excellent matrix for molecular basket sorbents (MBS) used in CO2 capture [32]. Thus TUD-1 can be an excellent support for reactions involving CO2 fixation. Moreover, Ag-TUD-1 catalysts have been found to have good absorptive properties for ethylene/ethane separation [33]. For greener and sustainable synthesis, solvent-free methods are more favourable. Noble metals are recently being used in the solvent-free cycloaddition of CO2and epoxides [34]. However, SiO2 supported silver particles haven't been yet studied for the purpose. Hereby, we report the TUD-1 supported silver nanoparticle catalysts for the conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates via cycloaddition with epoxides. 2 Experimental details 2.1 Materials For the synthesis, Tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) and Silver nitrate (AgNO3) were acquired from Sigma Aldrich. Triethanolamine (97%) was taken from ACROS Organics, Tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH, 20%) was purchased from Merck, Germany. Mili-Q water was used to prepare the solutions. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The UV–Vis spectroscopy was carried out on an Agilent Carry 5000 UV–Vis spectrophotometer with double out-of-plane Littrow Monochromator and integral sphere of 110 mm. For the N2Physisorption study, Micrometrics Gas Sorption analyzer (Model: 3FLEX3500) was used. The samples were analysed after pre-treating them in high-vacuum at 573 K for 5 h. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded at 77 K. The surface area measurements and pore-size distribution were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and Non-Local Density Functional Theory (NLDFT) method respectively. The X-Ray diffraction (XRD) study involved RigakuSmartlab high resolution X-Ray Diffractometer (HRXRD) with Cu Kα radiation source. A measurement range of 1° to 100° and 2θ step size of 0.04° were taken . The X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on PHI 5000 Versa Probe III XPS instrument with 128-channel detector and monochromatic Al Kα radiation source operating at 24.1 W. Prior to XPS analysis, the sample powders were pelletized. The Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) was done using Thermo Scientific Talos F200X G2 microscope having accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Prior to TEM analysis, the ethanolic dispersion of the samples were drop-casted on copper grid with carbon film. The Selected Area Electron Diffraction (SAED) and Energy Dispersive X-Ray (EDAX) studies were also done with the TEM instrument. The ICP-AES measurement was done using ICAP 7400Duo ICP-AES instrument from Thermo fisher Scientific, USA. 2.3 Catalyst preparation 2.3.1 Synthesis of TUD-1 material Non-hydrothermal sol-gel method was used to synthesize TUD-1 ( Scheme 1 ) [30]. At first, 20.8 g of tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) was poured in a beaker and was kept in constant stirring condition. Afterwards, 29.8 g of triethanolamine (TEA) was added drop-wise on TEOS and the mixture was kept stirred for additional 10 min. Then, water and aqueous solution of tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH) were added (net weight of added TEAOH = 14.7 g) to facilitate gel (silatrene) formation [28]. The molar ratio of TEOS:TEA: TEAOH: H2O = 1:2:1:11 was maintained inside the mixture. After stirring the mixture of additional 24 h at room temperature, which was followed by drying at 100 °C for 24 h. The TUD-1 support was obtained by calcination of the mixture at 700 °C for 10 h at 1 °C min−1 rate in a muffle furnace. 2.3.2 Synthesis of Ag/TUD-1 catalysts The Ag/TUD-1 was prepared by impregnation method ( Scheme 1 ). In a typical procedure, AgNO3, equivalent to 4 wt% Ag was dissolved in water. After keeping the solution stirred for 15 min, TUD-1 was poured into the solution. After an additional 1 h of stirring, the solution temperature was increased to 80 °C to the evaporate water in the solution. After additional 24 h of drying, the Ag.TUD-1 catalyst was obtained after calcination of the material at 500 °C for 4 h at 1 °C min−1 rate. Catalysts with 2wt% and 6wt% of Ag loading were also prepared for comparison 2.4 Catalytic activity studies The cycloaddition reaction of epoxides with CO2 was carried out in a 100 mL high-pressure reactor with 2-(chloromethyl) oxirane (3 mmole), Ag/TUD-1 as a catalyst and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBABr) as a co-catalyst followed by the sealing of the reactor along with CO2 purging from the source. During the reaction, the temperature was monitored at 60 °C for 4 h along with constant stirring. Same method was followed for other substrates as well. After completion of reaction, the catalysts were recovered by centrifugation, washing with ethanol and further drying. The final product was extracted with ethyl acetate and H2O mixture and dried over sodium bicarbonate. The collected product was then evaporated under the reduced pressure. Finally, the product was characterised by 1H NMR in CDCl3 solution. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Structural and textural analysis The X-Ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Ag/TUD-1 and TUD-1 materials are shown in Fig. 1 . The broad hump at 22° represents the amorphous nature of TUD-1 [35] . The peaks due to metallic Ag can be detected at 38° and 44° in Ag/TUD-1 catalyst [36], representing the (111) and (200) planes. The crystallite size spacing of the Ag particles were determined to be approx. 44 nm from the Scherrer formula. The d-spacing of the (111) planes of the Ag particles were found to be 0.24 nm. Both the TUD-1 support and Ag/TUD-1 catalyst showed type IV isotherm and H3 hysteresis loop in the N2 physisorption isotherms at 77 K, owing to their irregular mesoporous structure ( Fig. 2 (a)). However, upon impregnation of Ag particles, the hysteresis loop transforms to H2 type. The pore structure and surface properties are shown in Table 1 . It can be observed that the surface area and pore volume of TUD-1 material decreases upon Ag impregnation, although the average pore size gets increased. The reason for the decrease in surface area might be the formation of larger Ag particles, which cover the TUD-1 surface. On the other hand, the increase in average pore size might be explained from The NLDFT pore size distributions of the TUD-1 and Ag/TUD-1 materials ( Fig. 2 (b)). The smaller pores (< 5 nm) are observed to be decreased after Ag impregnation on TUD-1. Thus, the smaller pores being completely covered by Ag particles, the N2 physisorption occurs predominantly at the larger pores, leading to increase in the average pore size of Ag/TUD-1 catalyst. 3.2 Spectroscopic studies The Ag/TUD-1 catalyst and the TUD-1 support can be distinguished by their colour even by naked eyes. While the TUD-1 support is white in colour, the Ag/TUD-1 catalyst shows dark yellow colour. The appearance of such colour in the Ag/TUD-1 material can be attributed to the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) by Ag nanoparticles, which can be detected by UV-Visible Absorption spectroscopy, from the absorption peak at 410 nm [37] ( Fig. 3 ) The X-Ray photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) survey spectra of TUD-1 show the O 1 s and Si 2p peaks at 100–108 eV and 530–538 eV ranges respectively for both the samples (ESI Supplementary Fig. S1.) In the TUD-1 support, the peaks around 532 eV in O1s spectra and 103 eV in Si 2p spectra indicates the Si-O-Si bonds, whereas the peaks around 534 eV in O1s spectra and 105 eV in Si 2p spectra designates the Si-OH bond [38,39]. However, upon the impregnation of Ag nanoparticles, the O 1 s and Si 2p peaks shifted to lower binding energy, which indicates the Ag-O-Si bonding interactions between Ag and TUD-1 support [40–42]. On the XPS analysis of the Ag 3d spectra ( Fig. 4 .), doublet of peaks can be observed, corresponding to the Ag 3d5/2 (368.07 eV) and Ag 3d3/2 (374.07 eV) states [43]. The Ag-3d spectra of the Ag/TUD-1 catalyst can be deconvoluted to peaks at 368 eV and 374 eV corresponding to the metallic Ag nanoparticles and peaks at 369 eV and 375 eV corresponding to the cationic silver species like Ag-O-Si. The high intensity of the metallic Ag peaks indicate that most of the Ag nanoparticles are in the zero oxidation state. However, the presence of Ag-O-Si bonds indicate that there is good interaction between the Ag species and TUD-1 systems [42]. However, to analyse the exact oxidation state of the Ag species, the Ag MNN Auger spectra was also recorded ( Fig. 5 ). The oxidation state of Ag was determined in terms of Auger parameter (α), which is calculated as: α = (Binding Energy of Ag 3d5/2) + (Kinetic Energy of Ag M4N45N45) The Auger parameter of Ag/TUD-1 material was found to be 726.07 eV, which corresponds to the metallic Ag species in that material [43]. 3.3 Microscopic study The transmission electron microscopy image of Ag/TUD-1 material shows the non-uniform structure of TUD-1 ( Fig. 6 (a) and 6(c)). The Ag nanoparticles follow a highly skewed log-normal distribution of the particle size ( Fig. 6 (b)), ranging from 2 nm to 70 nm, with mean of 24 nm and standard deviation of 15.7 nm. The log-normal distribution with a lower mean particle size and long tail towards higher Ag particle sizes suggest that particle migration and coalescence (PMC) might have occurred during the calcination of the Ag/TUD-1 catalyst [44]. The SAED pattern ( Fig. 6 (d)) of the catalyst also indicates the irregular structure, however Ag (111) reciprocal lattice point can be identified. The EDX analysis, shows the presence of Ag, Si and O, the weight percentage of Ag being 3.5 wt% (Supplementary Fig. S2). 3.4 Catalytic activity studies Primarily, optimization of the reaction conditions has been performed by choosing epichlorohydrine as model substrate for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction ( Scheme 2 ) [2,45,46] in the presence of Ag/TUD-1 and co-catalyst TBABr. Initially reaction temperature was fixed at room temperature and the pressure was varied from 0.1 MPa to 1 MPa to investigate the pressure effect. A maximum yield of 87% was obtained under 40 °C and 1 MPa pressure conditions. The yield apparently increased upon slight increase in temperature and 60 °C yielded a maximum of 98%, above which the yield substantially decreased ( Table 2 ). In order to confirm the role of catalyst, a controlled experiment was performed by the presence and absence of catalyst which was showed the change in yield from 62% to 16% at 60 °C for 1 h time duration (ESI Supplementary Fig. S3). Along with that the same reaction was carried out in absence of any co-catalyst at 60 °C and 1 MPa pressure was performed, but this combination of conditions without any co-catalyst was not satisfactory. The Table 2 also shows the optimized condition of pressure, temperature and time. The time duration plays an important role for this reaction to happen and our optimization for 1 h gave only 59% product under 1 MPa and 50 °C conditions. Upon screening the various time durations, the maximum yield was found when the duration was fixed to 4 h, above which there was no change in yield percentage. We have not used any solvents in the reaction suggesting the green and sustainable catalytic pathway over this Ag-catalyst. Another two batches of reactions were also carried out by following our recent previous works on cycloaddition reaction with Ce-MOF [47] and La-5-SIP MOF [48] in DCM and MeCN solvents, but there were no considerable changes in yield. The amount of catalyst plays a vital role in product yield as well. Initially we have started the reaction with 5 mg catalyst, it gave 40% yield ( Table 2 ). Upon increasing the amount of catalyst, the yield increased proportionally ( Fig. 7 .) and the highest yield was found when the catalytic amount was fixed to 15 mg. The substrate scope was thoroughly investigated with a series of epoxides and it gave 40 to 98% yield ( Table 3 ). For propylene oxide, the reaction was carried out at room temperature because of its high volatility. The optimized condition did not show any result for cyclohexane oxide, for this the maximum yield was found at 80 °C. To check the effect of silver loading in catalysis, a controlled experiment was performed by changing the amount of silver in TUD-1 ( Table 4 .). It was observed that, 4% of silver loading gives the maximum yield keeping other reaction parameters same. Above this loading there was no significant change in the product yield. A huge number of catalytic cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides have been reported over a large number of catalysts. But many literatures reported the use of solvent and required harsh reaction conditions [49,50]. In recent days solvent-free catalytic reaction is a challenging issue. With the continuous progress, various MOF and heterogeneous catalysts are already reported for the solvent free cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides [51,52]. Li et al. proposed a solvent free cyclic carbonate synthesis by using a novel 2D CdPIDA MOF at 80 °C and 2 MPa pressure [51]. Ji and his group report a metalloporphyrin based polymer intercalated with ionic liquids for cyclic carbonate synthesis at 1 MPa pressure and 80 °C [53]. Recently Esghi and Khalifeh et al. design well dispersed gold NPs in to the multi amine functionalized SBA-15 for solvent free CO2 fixation into the epoxides at 100 °C and 1 MPa pressure [54]. Herein we have reported the solvent free cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with a range epoxide in presence of Ag/TUD-1 catalyst at mild optimized conditions. 3.5 Probable mechanism The probable mechanism for the formation of cyclic carbonates over Ag/TUD-1 catalysts have been shown in Fig. 8 . This typical cycloaddition reaction of epoxides with CO2 follows the co-ordination insertion mechanism [34,55–57]. In the first step, CO2 is activated by the metallic Ag species [58]. In the next step, the epoxide forms adduct with the Ag nanoparticles and the acidic silica surface. The formation of adduct accelerates the ring opening of the epoxide by the nucleophilic attack on its less-hindered site by the Br− ion from TBABr co-catalyst [34,57,59]. As a result, oxyanion is generated and it attacks the electrophilic carbon of CO2. The oxygen atom of CO2, which was earlier attached to the Ag atoms of Ag/TUD-1, then attacks the epoxide, the C-Br bond is broken and Br− exits from the molecule. As a result, the cycloaddidion is completed and the cyclic carbonate is formed. 3.6 Recyclability test To check the heterogenicity of the materials we have performed the recyclability test ( Fig. 9 .). The recyclability experiment was done by collecting the catalyst after each cycle using centrifugation method. The collected catalyst was washed with methanol and put in to oven for further test. After several cycle it was shows the steadiness in its performance only a slight change in yield. A hot filtration test was performed by removing the catalyst from the reaction mixture after 2 h then the reaction was allowed to continue without catalyst for more 2 h. No notable change in yield was found which suggest the no leaching in metal in solution (ESI Supplementary Fig. S4). 4 Conclusion To summarize, metallic silver nanoparticles have been impregnated over high surface area TUD-1 type mesoporous silica support and the prepared Ag/TUD-1 catalyst has been characterized by UV-Visible Spectroscopy, XPS, TEM, N2 BET physisorption techniques. The Ag/TUD-1 catalyst was used for the fixation of CO2 into epoxides in a high-pressure reactor using TBABr as a co-catalyst. The process showed maximum yield of 98% upon the reaction of CO2 with epichlorohydrine at 60 °C temperature and 1 MPa pressure. Without catalyst (Ag/TUD-1) and co-catalyst (TBABr) the reaction didn't proceed satisfactorily. Upon variation of the substrate from epichlorohydrine to propylene epoxide, the maximum yield of 99% was achievable, at even lower temperature of 25 °C. The reactions occurred in a greener route due to solvent-free procedure, and at lower temperature compared to many similar reported reactions. The efficiency of the catalyst is attributed to the high adsorption ability and acidity of the TUD-1silica surface, which aids in the activation of the epoxide and the capability of the metallic Ag particles for activating the CO2 molecules. coredata.dc:description: Utilization of abandoned CO2 that is generated from fossil fuels and industrial sources into valuable chemicals is a smart approach for a greener future. The fixation of CO2 over epoxides and the production of cyclic carbonates is one of the popular CO2 utilization techniques. Silica supported silver nanoparticles have been used before in different important reactions like nitrophenol reduction, alcohol oxidation etc., due to the high surface area, pore size of silica and high activity of the Ag0 species. In this study, Technische Universiteit Delft -1 (TUD-1) is used as silica support for stabilizing silver nanoparticles and CO2 has been converted to cyclic carbonate under solvent less condition. The Lewis acidic nature of the silver particles have aided into the solvent-less CO2 conversion, resulting into the maximum yield of 98% at 60 °C and 1 MPa pressure.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of cyclic carbonates of different epoxides using CO2 as a C1 building block over Ag/TUD-1 mesoporous silica catalyst: A solvent free approach
